articles.headline: Arab Nations Strike in Libya, Surprising U.S.
articles.snippet: The airstrikes against Islamist-allied militias were a major escalation by the bloc of nations seeking to roll back Islamist gains since the Arab Spring.
articles.abstract: The airstrikes against Islamist-allied militias were a major escalation by the bloc of nations seeking to roll back Islamist gains since the Arab Spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Twice in the last seven days, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates have secretly launched airstrikes against Islamist-allied militias battling for control of Tripoli, Libya, four senior American officials said, in a major escalation of a regional power struggle set off by Arab Spring revolts.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Future of Export-Import Bank Is Wild Card in Key Senate Races
articles.snippet: The reauthorization of the agency that offers loans to foreign buyers of American products has become a source of friction in high-profile campaigns.
articles.abstract: The reauthorization of the agency that offers loans to foreign buyers of American products has become a source of friction in high-profile campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In North Carolina, Senator Kay Hagan, a Democrat, is siding with big business in her support of the Export-Import Bank of the United States and attacking Thom Tillis, her Republican challenger who opposes the bank but is endorsed by big business.

articles.headline: What’s Twitch? Gamers Know, and Amazon Is Spending $1 Billion on It
articles.snippet: Twitch, a hugely popular streaming video service, has helped turn gaming into a spectator event as much as a participatory activity.
articles.abstract: Twitch, a hugely popular streaming video service, has helped turn gaming into a spectator event as much as a participatory activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video in video games is suddenly a billion-dollar business.

articles.headline: Obama Authorizes Air Surveillance of ISIS in Syria
articles.snippet: The flights approved by President Obama would be a precursor to broader airstrikes against Sunni militants, which are already taking place in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The flights approved by President Obama would be a precursor to broader airstrikes against Sunni militants, which are already taking place in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has authorized surveillance flights over Syria, a precursor to potential airstrikes there, but a mounting concern for the White House is how to target the Sunni extremists without helping President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: On To-Do List: Deposit Cash in Bitcoin A.T.M.
articles.snippet: Automated machines that turn traditional money into virtual currency are cropping up, which supporters say could help the machines become as widespread as traditional bank A.T.M.s.
articles.abstract: Automated machines that turn traditional money into virtual currency are cropping up, which supporters say could help the machines become as widespread as traditional bank A.T.M.s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the A.T.M. of the future, where customers insert cash and leave with nothing.

articles.headline: French Economy Minister, Arnaud Montebourg, Was Often Out of Step With President
articles.snippet: Mr. Montebourg, who is expected leave French government, represents a leftist strand of Socialism that remains politically popular.
articles.abstract: Mr. Montebourg, who is expected leave French government, represents a leftist strand of Socialism that remains politically popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Arnaud Montebourg, France’s combative economy minister, learned in April that Alstom, one of the country’s biggest industrial companies, had been secretly negotiating its takeover by General Electric, he responded by publicly castigating the French company’s boss.

articles.headline: Absorbing Events Past in a Summer’s Reading List
articles.snippet: Andrew Ross Sorkin’s summer reading list on the meanderings of business, finance and technology.
articles.abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin’s summer reading list on the meanderings of business, finance and technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the summer comes to an end, I’ve been trying to squeeze as much reading as I can into the final days. A benefit of this job is the opportunity to get sneak peeks at books before they are released, so I’ve been catching up on a pile of books that I missed earlier in the year as well as trying to get ahead by polishing off a couple that won’t be published until later this fall. So while Amazon’s Jeff Bezos continues to battle it out with Hachette (now that should be a book!), here’s a list of highlights from my summer reading list that I hope will appeal to your inner financial geek:

articles.headline: Courting Tim Hortons, Burger King Has Plans for a Fast-Food Empire
articles.snippet: After years of cost-cutting, Burger King is ready to spend more than $8 billion on the Canadian chain of coffee-and-doughnut shops.
articles.abstract: After years of cost-cutting, Burger King is ready to spend more than $8 billion on the Canadian chain of coffee-and-doughnut shops.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Daniel Schwartz took over as chief executive of Burger King last year, he set about pinching pennies.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Election Panel Enacts Policies by Not Acting
articles.snippet: Deadlocked votes by the Federal Election Commission have created a rapidly expanding universe of unofficial law, particularly on financial disclosure and investigations.
articles.abstract: Deadlocked votes by the Federal Election Commission have created a rapidly expanding universe of unofficial law, particularly on financial disclosure and investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The three Republican and three Democratic appointees of the Federal Election Commission had reached yet another deadlock: They would issue no advisory opinion on whether the Conservative Action Fund could accept contributions of Bitcoin, the online currency created to be untraceable.

articles.headline: Cease-Fire Extended, but Not on Hamas’s Terms
articles.snippet: The long-term deal, proposed by Egypt, halts the longest, bloodiest battle either side has experienced in years, but without resolving many of the bigger issues underlying the conflict.
articles.abstract: The long-term deal, proposed by Egypt, halts the longest, bloodiest battle either side has experienced in years, but without resolving many of the bigger issues underlying the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After 50 days of fighting that took some 2,200 lives, leveled large areas of the Gaza Strip and paralyzed Israel’s south for the summer, Israeli and Palestinian leaders reached an open-ended cease-fire agreement on Tuesday that promised only limited change to conditions in Gaza and left unresolved the broader issues underpinning the conflict.
